Settings.SourceText: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1031{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Courier New;}} \viewkind4\uc1\pard\lang1033\f0\fs30 The flora and fauna of the Ice Age differ dramatically from that of today. A new study focusing on the \par\par birds of the Ice Age has shed light on the long-term response of birds to climate change. The research \par\par shows that the population of British birds in the Ice Age was larger suggesting the richness of the \par\par environment at this time. John Stewart from Bournemouth University and researcher Roger Jacobi found out \par\par that there was an unusual mix of birds in one space and a distinct dawn chorus. The mixtures of birds that \par\par lived together were different from anywhere in the world today. Birds exotic to Britain, such as species \par\par normally expected in the tundra to the north, the Mediterranean to the South or the Eastern steppes lived \par\par together with birds expected in the region today. John Stewart stated: \'93It is clear that the change of \par\par prehistoric birds in Britain resembles that of mammals. It also signifies that the dawn chorus witnessed \par\par by the Neanderthals at that time and place has no parallels anywhere today.\'94}
